fields.title: Why should you teach your kids to code
fields.content:
Nowadays children learn to use a smartphone even before they start counting. They not only use it to play games but also use different kinds of applications. They can easily change wallpapers, ringtones or even download their favorite games from the application store.

First of all, let us understand how children learn such tasks so easily and quickly without much help from teachers and parents?

The answer is simple. Children pick up any concept easily if it is :
Visual in nature instead of blob of text.
Interactive in nature instead of theoretical.

 

Both of the above are present when they use a smartphone. This should give us a hint, how to present our lessons to children to maximize their learning.

Coding also falls in the same category. It helps children learn important and valuable life skills without even realizing them. That is one of the many reasons why a parent should think of teaching their children to code.

 

There are several other promising rationales to convince you that it is not only interesting but also important in the current times. Following are some of the other benefits of coding

Getting better at basic Mathematics
Coding involves analyzing the problem at hand and breaking down into smaller subproblems. And solving each subproblem requires attention and patience. Practicing this enables them to overcome the fear of mathematics.

Critical Thinking
Coding involves taking a decision at every line. This naturally makes student critical thinkers. It introduces them to some of the disciplines of STEM.

Perseverance
This is something important. Programming is not a magic wand, that does everything as we order. Instead, you need to pass clear and correct instructions. Failing to do so, the computer doesn't show the result as we expect. It asks us to try different methods continuously. This cycle of trial and error teaches a necessary skill.

Being creative
When children start creating even small things, they get the confidence to do harder things. This quality is very useful in the sense that they'll not become consumers but creators too.

The skill of the future
Last but not least coding is one of the most desired skills of the future.

The benefits are large and the possibilities endless. Choosing not to teach coding will only make their learning curve in the STEM discipline a bit steep. We would recommend you to try because it is really worth giving one!

fields.title: Method Chaining in Pandas library
fields.content:
In this post, I’m sharing some basic tips on how to use the Pandas Python library for the beginners.

If you’ve just started out with pandas library you might have been overwhelmed by the functionalities it provides to us. Sometimes when we see several methods chained together, it looks like magic but once you get basics right, it'd is fun to write such expression.

Before we jump in, guess what is the value stored in result for given dataframe :

a b type
1 2 cat
2 1 cat
3 3 dog
4 4 dog

 

import pandas as pd
import numpy as npdf = pd.DataFrame({‘a’:[1,2,3,4],’type’:[‘cat’,’cat’,’dog’,’dog’],’b’:[2,1,3,4]})

result = df.select_dtypes(include = [np.number,’object’])
           .groupby(‘type’)
           .sum()
           .sort_values(ascending = False,by = ‘b’)
           .reset_index()
           .a
           .apply(lambda x : x+10)
           .astype(‘int64’)
           .mean()

 

If your answer is 15.0 you probably don’t need these tips.:) For those who couldn’t get the right answer. Please continue.

Pro Tip: Always remember the object you’re working with and what kind of object is returned after applying a method on it.

Let’s apply it on the above example :

df: is an object of DataFrame.

df.select_dtypes(include = [np.number,’object’]) : returns an object of DataFrame.

.groupby(‘type’) : returns an object of DataFrameGroupBy. So we need to be careful now, because we can no longer apply DataFrame methods. We can only apply the methods and attributes of DataFrameGroupBy.

.sum(): returns an object of DataFrame. So now again we can apply methods available for DataFrame.

.sort_values(ascending = False,by = ‘b’): returns an object of DataFrame.

.reset_index() : returns again a DataFrame.

.a : Selects a column using dot notation and returns an object of Series. So now we can apply only those methods which are available for Series object.

.apply(lambda x: x+10) : returns an object of Series.

.astype(‘int64’) : Casts each value of a series into int64 and returns an object of Series.

.mean(): returns an object of numpy.float64.

Conclusion

When you know the object you’re working with, you can chain as many methods as needed and you don’t mix up the methods of different objects. Also it saves you from creating many redundant variable.

fields.title: Data privacy and it's importance for everyone
fields.content:
Data privacy is directly related to the collection, storage, and usage of data. With the ever-growing use of technology in our daily lives, we are all giving away and using data from various sources for different purposes. Data privacy is a term that aims to strike a balance between the collection of data and it's intended commercial usage. It is as important as

Before diving deep into the importance of data privacy, let's first understand:

What is privacy?

Privacy is the ability of an individual to not share their private information without necessarily revealing the reason for it.

So why is it important in today's context?

People aren't comfortable sharing their private information. That is one of the reasons why they build homes with doors, windows and locks.

It doesn't necessarily mean that they are doing something wrong. That is the way they are.

Just to clarify:

Data is the raw fact about something.

Information is the collection of useful facts from raw data

Data and information are two different terms. For the simplicity of the article, they are used interchangeably.

So, back to data privacy. It is also known as data security or information security. Data is collected from us all the time. It aims to give control to the individual about the collection, storage, and intended usage of their data.

Whether we are sharing locations from our smartphones to various applications, just signing up on different websites, using search engines for daily needs or simply browsing through the ever-increasing social media platforms, we are in a cycle that collect a lot of our personal data in response to the information given to us. Hence we need to be concerned.

Data security has implications in the fields of the Internet, finance, politics, etc. Let's try to understand some of them in detail.

Internet

A lot of our daily communications occur through the Internet. Emails and messages need to be encrypted so that they aren't read by any third-party. The repurcussions of the breach are well documented as in 2016 Presidential elections of US.

Not only communications, we share a lot of information on social media platforms. This information if not handled carefully may lead to cyberstalking and damages to reputation.

Finance

Financial transactions reveal a lot about an individual's identity. They include sensitive information like their assets, stocks, bank-details. If this information lands into an unintended hand may lead to cyber fraud or identity theft.

In some cases, such information is used by corporations for target marketing, sometimes even without the permission of the individual.

Voting

Try to keep the voter's opinion secret has been an established practice since ancient times. Voters' choice needs to be kept private in order to allow them to use their democratic rights without any apprehensions. Sadly, they aren't any current digital voting mechanisms that are foolproof, they have concerns regarding privacy and data theft.

Politics

The government collects a lot of citizen data. The data is intended to be used for purposes like identification, security, providing subsidies, etc.

While this intention appears to be a noble one, there have been cases in the past where this information has been used for suppressing protests against the government.

In some cases, when this data is collected by private parties, concerns have risen that amount from privacy to data security.

Conclusion

Hence we need to realize the importance of keeping data privacy in the current environment. We need to be careful before sharing our personal information with an unidentified source. A lot of the countries have strict data laws but we need others also to follow suit.

fields.title: New features in Python 3.8
fields.content:
Python's latest version at the time of writing this article is 3.8.1. It was released on December 18, 2019. In this post, we list some of the new features in this version as compared to Python 3.7

  • Walrus Assignment Operator
  • Position only parameter
  • Using = specifier with f-strings
  • Syntaxwarning
  • Improved math and statics function

 

Walrus Assignment Operator

  • One of the biggest change in this version is the introduction of assignment operator. They are represented using the symbol  :=
  • They are also known as walrus operator due to their resembelance to the eyes and tusks of a walrus.
  • They are generally used to assign and return values in the same expression.

 

For example in Python 3.7

foo = "something"
print (something)

In Python 3.8 we could write this as

print (foo:="something")
  • The walrus operator can also be used inside if or while blocks that calculate a value to test a particular condition.

 

# Check whether the first element of the list is 24
while (foo:= a[0]) == 24:
    process (foo)

Position Only Parameter 

  • The new function parameter syntax /  which indicates for some function parameters to be specified positionally. They can't be used as keyword assignments. 

 

# a, b are positional only arguments

def foo(a, b, /, c, d):
    print (a, b, c, d)

# You can use these as function calls
foo (8, 9, 10, d=11)

# These are invalid calls
foo(a=8, 9, 10, 11)
foo(8, b=9, 10, 11)
  • One possible use case of positional arguments would be to disallow use of keyword argument when argument name is not helpful. Consider the following example

 

# The definition of the built-in python function len
len(obj, /)
    Return the number of items in a container.

>>> len(foo="something")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: len() takes no keyword arguments
  • Another benefit of marking an argument as position only is that it allows change of argument name in the future, without breaking the code

Using = specifier with f-strings

  • One of my favourite addition is the support of = operator to f-strings specifiers. This can be really helpful in debugging and self - documenting expressions.

 

In Python 3.7 we would use

#python 3.7
>>> num = 8
>>> print ("num=",num)
num= 8

 In Python 3.8, we would simple write this as

# python 3.8
>>> num = 8
>>> print(f'{num=}')
num=8

Syntax Warning

Syntax Warning helps in better debugging and coding purposes. Rather than just displaying a SyntaxError, in this example the compiler displays SyntaxWarning as well

>>> [(10, 20) (30, 40)]
<stdin>:1: SyntaxWarning: 'tuple' object is not callable; perhaps you missed a comma?
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: 'tuple' object is not callable

Improved Math and Statistics Function

A couple of functions have been added to the math module. Some of them are

  • math.prod

A function that analogous to the sum function returns the product of a 'start' value(default: 1) times an iterable of numbers.

>>> import math
>>> lst = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
>>> math.prod(lst)
120
  • math.isqrt

math.isqrt() computes accurate integer square roots without conversion to floating point. It supports arbitrarily large integers. According to the documentation

It is faster than floor(sqrt(n)) but slower than math.sqrt()

>>> math.isqrt(9)
3
>>> math.isqrt(15)
3
>>> math.sqrt(15)
3.872983346207417

A lot more changes have been incorporated in Python 3.8. For a more comphrehensive list of changes you can have a look at the official documentation.

fields.title: Increase in spam call by 18% in 2019
fields.content:
According to the report published on truecaller blog spam calls grew by 18% this year in 2019. The firm based in Stockholm said that it had helped block about 26 billion spam calls this year. The corresponding statistics for 2018 at about 17.1 million.

Key Insights

Brazil tops the list, India is on 5th while the USA stands on 8th.

Most Latin American countries have seen a dramatic increase in the number of spam calls.

The country with the biggest increase in total spam calls is Indonesia, which saw it jump from 16 last year to 3 this year.

Brazil

Brazil continues to be at top of the list. Quoting the report

Almost every other spam call in Brazil is being made from the operators and Internet service providers. In the past 12 months, calls from the operators have increased from 32% to 48%

India

Although India has slipped down to fifth from being at the top in 2017, the country saw an increase of about 15% this year. The report attributes the telecom operator as one of the major spammers. In addition to this, the report says

However, with the rise of mobile payments and a growing middle class in India, we have seen banks, fin-tech companies, and outsourced telemarketing services emerging as big spammers.

The report also sites that 1 out of every 3 women in India receive sexual harassment or inappropriate calls or SMS on a regular basis.

USA

The United States continues to be the eighth-most spammed country. The report blames the increasing robocalls to be the main offender.

Comparing with last year, the number of robocalls has increased from 7% to a staggering 35% – which means that more than every third spam call a user gets is a robocall.

 

One of the main reasons for the increase is attributed to the ever-increasing usage of phones in daily life. They have become an undifferentiable part of our life and have made all of us much more accessible.

The report also shows the countries most affected by spam SMS.

fields.title: The Importance of STEAM Education
fields.content:
In this post we'll briefly discuss what is STEAM education, why has it become important very important in this current age and what steps should we take to expose students towards this field?

STEAM stands for Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics. 

 So what's so special about this?

It is special in the sense that the

STEAM field encourages students into thinking about the problem, conceptualizing the solution, building on the solution, failing once or twice or more, then reassessing about the approach and repeat.

Our current education seems to under-emphasize this concept and instead gets lost in some curriculum.

There are different methods, techniques but the core idea remains the same. So now we know a bit about what is STEAM education. Let's understand why has it become important these days.

Importance of STEAM

According to this report by an economics forecast company Oxford Economics, robotics will displace 20 million jobs worldwide. This roughly represents 8.5% of the global manufacturing source. We just can't ignore this. We should not. Given the pace at which technology is advancing these predictions appear to be true to the present.

So what's the solution? Be creative. Think Critically.

What does thinking critically mean?
Critically thinking is the process of understanding, analyzing a set of observations and then coming up with some solutions or insights.

How all of these apply to a kid's education? Why should you bother all these things about your child? The answer is clear. They need to be prepared for the future. Currently, they are learning skills that will become obsolete. That's why we need to take steps towards this problem.

Students at an early age behave like a sponge, ready to absorb from every experience they have.

They are critical thinkers naturally. But here is the catch. This aspect doesn't last for long, for a mind to remain curious it has to be consistently fanned and fueled, absence of this will cause the critical thinking and curiosity to fade away slowly.

Last question, what steps should we take to expose kids towards this field?

We need our teachers and parents who can arouse curiosity, develop their thought process, help them understand the working of small devices to this humongous universe and so on.

Conclusion

In short, we should look to encourage every student's process to be a critical thinker, innovator, maker, and last but not the least we help them create the future.

fields.title: What is Artificial Intelligence?
fields.content:
Artificial Intelligence is on everyone’s mouth - Engineers, Entrepreneurs, Investors, Government, Journalists, etc. Now and then we get some inspiring news like AI helps blind people see, AI Accurately Detects Lung Cancer in Scans. And some scary news like - AI generates fake news, more serious fake videos.

So what is Artificial Intelligence - It is the field of study which enables machines for decision-making abilities. In the entire history, humans are considered unique among all species because of its one special characteristics called - Intelligence. Half a century ago only a few would have imagined that a machine could read handwriting, speak fluently in natural language, cure diseases, etc. But now it’s possible and we are the first generation to witness this incredible achievement.

Why Now

It didn’t take off all of a sudden. The research was going on in this field for nearly half a decade. All the shiny results that we see today comes from a small sub-field of AI called Deep Learning. The 2012 results on ImageNet classification challenge sparked interest in this field. And the availability of high computing power and large storage at a relatively cheap rate made it possible to expedite the advancements in this field.

Applications of Artificial Intelligence

There are countless applications of AI. Easy availability of tools and resources has made it possible for companies of all sizes to integrate it into their products. The most common fields in which AI has established success are healthcare, self-driving cars, human-vs-computer games, visual recognition, speech recognition, machine translation, natural language processing, etc.

Challenges of AI

Despite being hugely successful in areas like computer vision and natural language processing, there are some flaws that can't be overlooked. AI remains in news for being biased on the basis of sex, color, race, etc. It happens not because AI has formed its own opinion but due to this kind of biasedness present in the data. There are also challenges like :

  • Explainability and Interpretability
  • Legal Issues
  • Data availability

Impact of AI

While AI is improving at a very fast rate, it has become a matter of concern, whether it will lead to mass unemployment. The advent of self-driving cars, skilled robots, virtual assistants have already started to replace humans. According to a report, just by 2021, intelligent agents and related robots will have eliminated a net 6% of jobs.

 

Conclusion

Whether we believe it or not, our life is already affected by artificial intelligence. Be it Google Assistant, search engine result, amazon product recommendations, Facebook image analysis and so on. For a better future, we need to ensure AI remains open, accessible and useful for all instead of closed or centralized, inaccessible to common people and useful to only a handful of people.

fields.title: Top 10 Programming Languages to learn in 2020
fields.content:
Programming languages are evolving at an unprecedented rate. Every year we observe some of it going less popular or obsolete and some of them gaining tremendous popularity. As a beginner or even experienced developer, you need to stay updated to gain the maximum benefits in terms of career prospects. It doesn’t take too much time to change the landscape of technology.

Here is the list of the top 10 programming languages

Python

Python has made programming incredibly fun and easy. It has helped people from wildly different fields (Medical, Law, Physics, etc) to learn to code easily. It has many superpowers — Easy syntax, tons and tons of packages, community support, online resources.

Javascript

When it comes to the web, there is only one leader — Javascript. There are definitely ups and downs in libraries and frameworks but the language stays relevant. You should seek proficiency in this if you wish to create web applications.

Go(lang)

It’s relatively new entrant but its dominance is increasing every day. It makes it easy to build simple, reliable, and efficient software. Go is an open-source project developed and actively maintained by google.

C++

It was released in October 1985 by Bjarne Stroustrup. Since then it has matured enough to stay for many more decades to come. If you want to create something that requires high performance, efficiency, resource-constraints then C++ is the best language to choose.

Java

3 billion devices run Java. Need I say more? Java is the current leader and no one seems even closer to it in Android development. But it’s only limited to this it’s also widely used in desktop GUI applications, web servers and application servers, etc.

Swift

It is a general-purpose language developed by tech giant Apple. If you want to develop high-quality native iOS or Mac OS apps then look no further.

Julia

It gives you the best of both worlds — Syntax like Python and Speed like C and Go. It’s also open-source and well-suited for high-performance numerical analysis and computational science.

C#

This language is must learn if you’re planning to create software applications for Microsoft platform either for hobby purpose or industry standard. Some great examples of its use case are — Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, etc ), Adobe Photoshop, Skype.

R

Though its popularity is overpowered by Python but R is still highly used mainly for data analysis. There are some really beautiful packages like ggplot2 and powerful package dplyr, caret.

SQL

While SQL is not generally used as a general-purpose programming language but its capability is beyond any description. If you are starting or working with a structured form of data then you master this classic query language.

 

There is one thing we should keep in mind; there’s no best language and worst language. It depends on your purpose, experience, and requirements. If you’re just starting out, you can choose Python and then switch to another language later on.
fields.tags: programming-language python c++ java julia swift go sql

fields.title: Introduction to Object-oriented Programming
fields.content:
If you've ever written code that had a lot of repetitive components with very little variation, a long list of arguments in functions, and very hard to identify which components are related to which. These problems are inevitable if the codebase is started without any structure in mind and its size becomes a bit large. Besides knowing other software development practices you should also know some programming paradigms which is a very important concept in Computer Science. In this post, we'll start with Object-oriented.

What Is Object-Oriented Programming?

Object-oriented Programming is one of the most popular programming-paradigm which works on the concept of objects.

The best thing about OOP is code re-usability. It means once we define the blueprint of any object we just have to create an object and voila, we have access to all the methods and attributes of that object.

Objects can have data and code in the form of attributes and methods respectively.

Most popular OOP languages are class-based, which means we first define the class and then create an instance of those classes. We call those instances as an object.

Common OOP languages are Python, C++, Java, C#. These languages are not OOP entirely but they do support most of the concepts.

The following are common concepts of OOP

1. Encapsulation

2. Abstraction

3. Inheritance

4. Polymorphism

which we’ll learn in this series one by one.

fields.title: Introduction to Robotics
fields.content:
Before trying to understand robotics, let us first be clear on what are robots. They are different versions from different people on what they categorize as robots. On that is most agreed upon is that :

Robots are a machine capable of reducing human efforts by performing a complex set of tasks automatically.

They are programmable by computers and may be controlled by an external source or a source embedded inside them. Autonomous cars, voice assistants, humanoids, etc. are all examples of robots.

Now coming back to Robotics

Robotics is the branch of engineering that deals with the designing, construction, control, usage, etc. of the robots.

It is an interdisciplinary branch that includes but isn't confined to computer science, electronics, mechanical, information engineering, etc.

Why is it interesting

There is a reason this field excites every technological enthusiast. It is really fascinating to see the latest discoveries. There are reasons that drive people towards working in this field.

  • Robotics tries to mix the best of the worlds of hardware and software.
  • It aims to automate the risky, tedious and boring stuff so that humans can concentrate on other problems(there are a lot of them, believe me!).

 

What are the concerns

The drastic evolution and the ever-growing usage of robotics in our daily lives has also raised a few valid concerns.

  • While robots have increased productivity and efficiency in most fields, according to a report published in Oxford Economic Forum estimate, up to 20 million manufacturing jobs are set to be lost to robots by 2030.
  • All robots aren't that safe. There is a reason fenced robots in manufacturing are fenced.
  • This concern is not much of an issue considering the current scenario but needs to be addressed in the future. Robotics in combination with Artificial Intelligence could be  used against humans
  • The world still suffers from the waste disposal issues, electronics waste disposal only adds to its concerns.

 

What is the future

Robots have entered almost all fields and threaten to broaden their scope every day. The constant evolution in the fields of artificial intelligence, quantum computing, etc has opened up more avenues for robotics.

  • Drone deliveries have just started but it will surely be a thing to watch out for.
  • All Terrain Robots (ATR) will be used for successfully rescuing people from forests and areas where humans would take a lot more time to reach. Research regarding this was published by the National Science Foundation, United States of America in 2011.
  • RoboCup, an organization is working on building robots that can win a soccer game in FIFA 2050. This would really be a spectacle to watch. Their objective in their own words:

By the middle of the 21st century, a team of fully autonomous humanoid robot soccer players shall win a soccer game, complying with the official rules of FIFA, against the winner of the most recent World Cup.

Currently, robots are driving cars, patrolling (UAV - unmanned aerial vehicles), cooking and what not but most of these fields are yet developing. This is both exciting as well as scary.

fields.title: Top 10 Programming Quotes.
fields.content:
"Any fool can write code that a computer can understand. Good programmers write code that humans can understand."  - Martin Fowler

"Code is like humor. When you have to explain it, it’s bad."  - Cory House

"Fix the cause, not the symptom."  - Steve Maguire

"When to use iterative development? You should use iterative development only on projects that you want to succeed."   - Martin Fowler

"Before software can be reusable it first has to be usable."   - Ralph Johnson

"Optimism is an occupational hazard of programming: feedback is the treatment."  - Kent Beck

"Walking on water and developing software from a specification are easy if both are frozen."  - Edward V Berard

"Talk is cheap. Show me the code."  - Linus Torvalds

"Most of you are familiar with the virtues of a programmer. There are three, of course: laziness, impatience, and hubris."  - Larry Wall

"Always code as if the guy who ends up maintaining your code will be a violent psychopath who knows where you live."  - Martin Golding

Bonus quote 
 

"If builders built buildings the way programmers wrote programs, then the first woodpecker that came along would destroy civilization."  - Gerald Weinberg
